title: Heat Exhaustion
summary: Heat-related illness that can progress to heat stroke if untreated. Requires prompt cooling and rehydration.

steps.title: Identify Heat Exhaustion
steps.description: Heavy sweating, weakness, nausea, headache, muscle cramps, cool clammy skin, fast weak pulse, dizziness. Body temperature elevated but below 104°F. Person is usually still alert.

steps.title: Move to Cool Environment
steps.description: Get person to air-conditioned room or shady area immediately. Lay them down and elevate legs slightly. Loosen or remove tight clothing. If symptoms worsen or last >1 hour, call 911.

steps.title: Cool the Person
steps.description: Apply cool wet cloths to skin or have them take cool shower if able. Fan while misting with cool water. Place cool compresses on neck, armpits, and groin. Monitor temperature if possible.

steps.title: Rehydrate Slowly
steps.description: If fully alert and not nauseous, give cool water or sports drinks. Have them sip slowly - about 4 ounces every 15 minutes. Do not give if vomiting. Avoid alcohol or caffeine.

steps.title: Monitor for Improvement
steps.description: Symptoms should improve within 30-60 minutes. If person becomes confused, stops sweating, or temperature rises above 104°F, treat as heat stroke and call 911. Keep person resting in cool area.

warnings: Heat exhaustion can quickly progress to life-threatening heat stroke
Do not give salt tablets - these can worsen condition
If person has heart problems or is on low-sodium diet, seek medical care
whenToSeekHelp: Call 911 if symptoms worsen or don't improve within 1 hour
Seek immediate care if person becomes confused or stops sweating
Get medical help for severe symptoms or chronic medical conditions
preventionTips: Drink water before feeling thirsty in hot weather
Take frequent breaks in shade or air conditioning
